title: China Eximbank provides $235.2 million buyer's credit loan to Ethiopian Shipping Lines (ESL) for the construction of nine shipping vessels
description: On September 1, 2010, China Eximbank provided a $235.2 million buyer’s credit loan to Ethiopian Shipping Lines S.C (ESL or 俄比亚船运与物流公司举) for the construction of nine shipping vessels. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that the loan was backed by a sovereign guarantee and a Sinosure credit insurance policy. It is also known that the borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance 80% of the cost of a $294 million commercial contract between ESL and China Poly Group Corporation (中国保利集团有限公司), which was signed in 2010.    According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the $235.2 million (ETB 3,216,027,397) loan achieved a 28% disbursement rate, with China Eximbank making 3 loan disbursements (worth ETB 938,738,101) between 2011 and 2012: an ETB 172,782.818 disbursement on October 10, 2011, an ETB 117,749.135 disbursement on January 9, 2012, and an ETB 648,206,148 disbursement on October 10, 2012.    Of the nine vessels that the ESL purchased, seven were to be multi-purpose freighters and two to be oil tankers. The vessels, which were produced by Shandong Huanghai Shipbuilding and delivered by China Poly Group Corporation, were ordered by ESL around January 2011 and they were officially handed over to the Ethiopian Shipping and Logistics Service Enterprise (ESLESE) on May 17, 2014. ESLESE initially operated these nine vessels. However, according to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, the nine vessels are now being leased by a company other than ESLESE.
staff_comments: 1. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 87143122101160. 2. The AMP identifies the face value of the loan as ETB 3,216,027,397. 1 Ethiopian Birr (ETB) was equal to 0.06 United States Dollars (USD) in September 2010, which implies that the USD face value of the loan was $192,961,643.82. 3. The Chinese project title is 9艘货船. 4. For the time being, AidData assumes that this loan is backed by a sovereign guarantee because the Government of Ethiopia’s Ministry of Finance indicates in its Public Sector Debt Statistical Bulletin No. 15 that ‘government-guaranteed external debt comprises of loans and suppliers credits contracted by public enterprises, mainly the Ethiopian Electric Power (EEP), Ethiopian Electric Utility (EEU), Ethiopian Sugar Corporation, Ethiopian Railways Corporation, Ethiopian Shipping Lines and guaranteed by MoFED as well as the state owned bank — the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE).’ 5. China Poly Group Corporation is a state owned Chinese business group among 102 central state owned enterprises under the supervision of State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council. 6. ESLSE is a public-sector company that provides logistics shipping services (sea transport, agency services, stevedoring, and shore handling); clearing and freight forwarding by its MTS representation in Djibouti (customs clearance, port clearance, and road freight); and port and terminal services (receiving and delivering cargo, cargo loading and unloading, filling and emptying of containers, etc.). In 2011, Ethiopia decided to merge three organizations -- the former Ethiopian Shipping Lines S.C, Maritime and Transit Services Enterprise, and Dry Port Services Enterprise -- into a new company named the Ethiopian Shipping and Logistics Services Enterprise (ESLESE).7. According to Ethiopia's Ministry of Finance and Economic Development, the Government of Ethiopia signed a $234,766,400 loan agreement with China Eximbank for unspecified purposes on December 30, 2010. The loan carried the following borrowing terms: an interest rate of 3.067%, a grace period of 4 years, and maturity of 11 years. AidData currently captures the $234,766,400 loan as a separate, stand-alone record for an unspecified purpose (as captured via Project ID#30555). However, it is possible that this is the same loan that China Eximbank provided to Ethiopian Shipping Lines (ESL) for the construction of nine shipping vessels. This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Eximbank provides $235.2 million buyer's credit loan to Ethiopian Shipping Lines (ESL) for the construction of nine shipping vessels

# Description
On September 1, 2010, China Eximbank provided a $235.2 million buyer’s credit loan to Ethiopian Shipping Lines S.C (ESL or 俄比亚船运与物流公司举) for the construction of nine shipping vessels. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that the loan was backed by a sovereign guarantee and a Sinosure credit insurance policy. It is also known that the borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance 80% of the cost of a $294 million commercial contract between ESL and China Poly Group Corporation (中国保利集团有限公司), which was signed in 2010.    According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the $235.2 million (ETB 3,216,027,397) loan achieved a 28% disbursement rate, with China Eximbank making 3 loan disbursements (worth ETB 938,738,101) between 2011 and 2012: an ETB 172,782.818 disbursement on October 10, 2011, an ETB 117,749.135 disbursement on January 9, 2012, and an ETB 648,206,148 disbursement on October 10, 2012.    Of the nine vessels that the ESL purchased, seven were to be multi-purpose freighters and two to be oil tankers. The vessels, which were produced by Shandong Huanghai Shipbuilding and delivered by China Poly Group Corporation, were ordered by ESL around January 2011 and they were officially handed over to the Ethiopian Shipping and Logistics Service Enterprise (ESLESE) on May 17, 2014. ESLESE initially operated these nine vessels. However, according to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, the nine vessels are now being leased by a company other than ESLESE.
justification: Project involves construction of shipping vessels for general transportation purposes, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of nine shipping vessels (seven multi-purpose freighters and two oil tankers) for general transportation use

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 360 million interest-free loan for Pushkin Square-Gotera Interchange Road Project (Linked to Project ID#100 and ID#91947)
description: On December 27, 2016, the Ethiopian House of Representatives ratified an RMB 360 million (ETB 623,366,177) interest-free loan agreement with the Chinese Government for the Pushkin Square-Gotera Interchange Road Project (via Proclamation no. 986/2017). The ratification proclamation entered into force on January 12, 2017.   The interest-free loan was issued by the Agency for International Economic Cooperation within China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM). The loan proceeds were drawn from Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreements (ECTAs) that the Chinese Government and the Ethiopian Government had previously signed on July 20, 2010, April 18, 2011, August 15, 2011, January 28, 2012, October 29, 2012, and May 24, 2013.   The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance an RMB 308,526,277.10 commercial contract between Addis Ababa City Roads Authority and China First Highway Engineering Co., Ltd. According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the ETB 623,366,177 loan achieved a 132% disbursement rate, with MOFCOM making 4 loan disbursements (worth ETB 825,594,492) between 2020 and 2021: an ETB 194,164,377 disbursement on June 9, 2020, an ETB 565,829,909 disbursement on March 24, 2021, an ETB 12,455,390 disbursement on August 17, 2021, and an ETB 53,144,816 disbursement on October 13, 2021.  However, according to the AMP, MOFCOM ultimately decided to cancel RMB 310 million of the Government of Ethiopia’s loan repayment obligations (due to its debt sustainability problems). This act of debt forgiveness is captured via Project ID#91947.   The project will involve the construction of a 3.8 km road with a width of 30-45 meters that stretches from Pushkin Square to Gotera Interchange in Nifas Silk Laphto District. It has three segments: a 2.3 km road from Pushkin Square to the Gotera Interchange section stretches to 2.3 km and two feeder roads — Mauritius Street and Tanzania Street — that measure 1.5 km in length. The project also includes a two-lane 320 meter tunnel, bus rapid transit (BRT), and two interchanges. Upon completion, it was envisaged that the project will reduce traffic congestion in Addis Ababa and ensure the smooth flow of vehicles coming from Kirkos, Gotera, Gofa, Sar Bet, Mexico and Keria. The Gotera-Pushkin Square interchange is being built to accommodate three planned BRT lines that all intersect there: the B2 (under construction with AFD financing), the B3 (under construction with Korean ExIm financing), and the B6 (under construction with Korean ExIm financing), as well as decently integrated facilities for non-motorized travel.   China First Highway Engineering Co., Ltd., a subsidiary of CCCC, is the contractor responsible for project implementation. A consortium consisting of First Highway Consultant Co., Ltd and Xi'an Fangzhou Engineering Consulting Company Co. Ltd is responsible for project management. Best Consulting Engineers Private Limited Company is responsible for providing project consulting services.    A groundbreaking ceremony for the project took place on October 1, 2019. Liu Yu, Economic and Commercial Counsellor at the Embassy of China, Takele Uma, Mayor of Addis Ababa, Ahmed Shide, Ethiopia’s Minister of Finance, and Tan Jian, Chinese Ambassador to Ethiopia, attended the ceremony. Then, in May 2020, the Deputy Mayor of Addis Ababa conducted a project site visit and announced that the project was expected to reach completion within a year (May 2021). The project ultimately reached completion on August 15, 2022.  This project has faced local scrutiny and criticism due to the fact that it was reportedly the most expensive road project to ever be undertaken (in unit cost terms) in Ethiopia (at ETB 395 million per kilometer of road).   According to an October 2021 report, ‘Chinese engineers do not appear to have played a significant role in the conceptual design of the interchange. The BRT facilities that have been incorporated into the design have largely been designed by the consultants to the [French Development Agency, AFD], with input from ITDP Africa, and the main role of the Chinese firm building the road was to follow the designs made by other consultants. Th[is] trajectory indicates significant improvement on the part of Chinese-financed urban road projects over the course of the decade, with considerable progress still to be made, but this improvement appears to result primarily from the increasing sophistication of the Ethiopian government authorities rather than from any push from the Chinese ECAs or Chinese companies’.
staff_comments: 1.  Since loan terms for the interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set maturity period to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default per China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity period of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace. 2. This project is also known as the Pushkin to Goterra Road Project and the Alexander Pushkin Square-Gotera Interchange Road Project. 3. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 87143497127238. 4. 1 Ethiopian Birr (ETB) was equal to 0.50 RMB in July 2010 which implies that the loan commitment value recorded in the AMP (ETB 623,366,177) was equivalent to RMB 311,683,088.50 and the (total) loan disbursements value recorded in the AMP (ETB 825,594,492) was equivalent to RMB 412,797,246.
combined_text:

TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 360 million interest-free loan for Pushkin Square-Gotera Interchange Road Project (Linked to Project ID#100 and ID#91947)

# Description

The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to finance an RMB 308,526,277.10 commercial contract between Addis Ababa City Roads Authority and China First Highway Engineering Co., Ltd. According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the ETB 623,366,177 loan achieved a 132% disbursement rate, with MOFCOM making 4 loan disbursements (worth ETB 825,594,492) between 2020 and 2021: an ETB 194,164,377 disbursement on June 9, 2020, an ETB 565,829,909 disbursement on March 24, 2021, an ETB 12,455,390 disbursement on August 17, 2021, and an ETB 53,144,816 disbursement on October 13, 2021.  However, according to the AMP, MOFCOM ultimately decided to cancel RMB 310 million of the Government of Ethiopia’s loan repayment obligations (due to its debt sustainability problems). This act of debt forgiveness is captured via Project ID#91947. Best Consulting Engineers Private Limited Company is responsible for providing project consulting services.    A groundbreaking ceremony for the project took place on October 1, 2019. Liu Yu, Economic and Commercial Counsellor at the Embassy of China, Takele Uma, Mayor of Addis Ababa, Ahmed Shide, Ethiopia’s Minister of Finance, and Tan Jian, Chinese Ambassador to Ethiopia, attended the ceremony. This project has faced local scrutiny and criticism due to the fact that it was reportedly the most expensive road project to ever be undertaken (in unit cost terms) in Ethiopia (at ETB 395 million per kilometer of road).   According to an October 2021 report, ‘Chinese engineers do not appear to have played a significant role in the conceptual design of the interchange. The BRT facilities that have been incorporated into the design have largely been designed by the consultants to the [French Development Agency, AFD], with input from ITDP Africa, and the main role of the Chinese firm building the road was to follow the designs made by other consultants. Th[is] trajectory indicates significant improvement on the part of Chinese-financed urban road projects over the course of the decade, with considerable progress still to be made, but this improvement appears to result primarily from the increasing sophistication of the Ethiopian government authorities rather than from any push from the Chinese ECAs or Chinese companies’.
justification: The project primarily involves road construction and infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of 3.8 km road, tunnel, and interchanges; focus on traffic congestion reduction and urban mobility

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 60 million grant for Building of Two China-Ethiopia Friendship Schools Project
description: On January 11, 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ethiopia signed an RMB ETB 39,174,079 grant agreement for the Building of Two China-Ethiopia Friendship Schools Project. However, it subsequently upsized its grant commitment to approximately RMB 60 million (ETB 100,785,657). According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government ultimately provided (disbursed) ETB 100,785,657 in grant funding (representing a 257% disbursement rate vis-a-vis the original commitment amount from January 11, 2010). China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) made three grant disbursements in 2013 and 2014: an ETB 43,047,291 disbursement on April 8, 2014, an ETB 31,428,571 disbursement on September 8, 2014, and an ETB 26,309,795 disbursement on January 8, 2015.   The purpose of the project was to construct 2 China-Africa friendship primary schools: Bole Ethio-China Friendship School and Abay Primary School in the capital city of Addis Ababa. China Jiangsu International Economic and Technical Cooperation Group Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. It signed an RMB 60 million construction contract with the Addis Ababa Education Bureau in July 2013. Xie Wei, deputy general manager of China Jiangsu International Economic and Technical Cooperation Group Co., Ltd., signed the contract. On May 20, 2015, an official project handover ceremony was held for the 2 schools. Construction was completed in 20 months, which suggests that the project implementation start date was September 20, 2013.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Two China-Ethiopia Friendship Schools Construction Project and the China Africa Friendship Primary Schools Project. The Chinese project title is 中非友好小学交. 2. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 87143123101133. 3. The construction of these two schools was one of the measures taken by the Chinese Government to implement the fourth ministerial meeting of the 2009 China-Africa Cooperation Forum. 4. The AMP records a grant commitment value of ETB 39,174,079 on January 11, 2010. 1 Ethiopian Birr (ETB) was equal to 0.08 United States Dollars (USD) and 0.54 Chinese yuan (RMB) in January 2010, which implies that the ETB 39,174,079 grant commitment recorded in the AMP was worth USD 3,133,926.32 and RMB 21,154,002.66 at the time that it was contracted.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 60 million grant for Building of Two China-Ethiopia Friendship Schools Project

# Description
On January 11, 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ethiopia signed an RMB ETB 39,174,079 grant agreement for the Building of Two China-Ethiopia Friendship Schools Project. However, it subsequently upsized its grant commitment to approximately RMB 60 million (ETB 100,785,657). According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government ultimately provided (disbursed) ETB 100,785,657 in grant funding (representing a 257% disbursement rate vis-a-vis the original commitment amount from January 11, 2010). China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) made three grant disbursements in 2013 and 2014: an ETB 43,047,291 disbursement on April 8, 2014, an ETB 31,428,571 disbursement on September 8, 2014, and an ETB 26,309,795 disbursement on January 8, 2015.   The purpose of the project was to construct 2 China-Africa friendship primary schools: Bole Ethio-China Friendship School and Abay Primary School in the capital city of Addis Ababa. China Jiangsu International Economic and Technical Cooperation Group Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. It signed an RMB 60 million construction contract with the Addis Ababa Education Bureau in July 2013. Xie Wei, deputy general manager of China Jiangsu International Economic and Technical Cooperation Group Co., Ltd., signed the contract. On May 20, 2015, an official project handover ceremony was held for the 2 schools. Construction was completed in 20 months, which suggests that the project implementation start date was September 20, 2013.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of two primary schools, education sector focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides ETB 2.06 million grant for Biogas Project
description: According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government and the Government of Ethiopia signed an ETB 2,061,570 grant agreement for a Biogas Project on May 18, 2010. The purpose of this project was to provide biogas equipment to the Ethiopian Ministry of Water Resources and Energy. On June 28, 2012, the equipment was officially handed over to the Ethiopian Ministry of Water Resources and Energy. The Chinese Ambassador to Ethiopia, Xie Xiaoyan and the Minister of Water Resources and Energy, Alemayhu Teguin, signed the handover certificates on behalf of their respective governments.
staff_comments: 1. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 87143123101139. 2. The Chinese project title is 沼气设备
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government provides ETB 2.06 million grant for Biogas Project

# Description
According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government and the Government of Ethiopia signed an ETB 2,061,570 grant agreement for a Biogas Project on May 18, 2010. The purpose of this project was to provide biogas equipment to the Ethiopian Ministry of Water Resources and Energy. On June 28, 2012, the equipment was officially handed over to the Ethiopian Ministry of Water Resources and Energy. The Chinese Ambassador to Ethiopia, Xie Xiaoyan and the Minister of Water Resources and Energy, Alemayhu Teguin, signed the handover certificates on behalf of their respective governments.
justification: Project focuses on biogas equipment, which is a renewable energy source and supports low-carbon energy transition
evidence: Biogas project, renewable energy focus, equipment provided to Ministry of Water Resources and Energy

title: Chinese government grants 41 scholarships to Ethiopian students
description: In August 2010, the Chinese government granted 41 scholarships to Ethiopian students. Tewodros Habte, representing the Ethiopian Ministry of Education, said close to 70 per cent of China's scholarships to Ethiopia are in engineering fields.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese government grants 41 scholarships to Ethiopian students

# Description
In August 2010, the Chinese government granted 41 scholarships to Ethiopian students. Tewodros Habte, representing the Ethiopian Ministry of Education, said close to 70 per cent of China's scholarships to Ethiopia are in engineering fields.
justification: Scholarship program focused on education with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Scholarships granted for education, primarily in engineering fields

title: ZTE teaches computer science and IT course at University of Addis Ababa
description: In June 2010, ZTE began teaching a computer science and information technology training course at the University of Addis Ababa. The duration and value of this project is unknown.   According to the Chinese Embassy in Ethiopia, ZTE trained 300 engineers and IT technicians in Ethiopia before 2010, and planned to freely train 2,000 information technology-related talents for Ethiopia in 2010.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
ZTE teaches computer science and IT course at University of Addis Ababa

# Description
In June 2010, ZTE began teaching a computer science and information technology training course at the University of Addis Ababa. The duration and value of this project is unknown.   According to the Chinese Embassy in Ethiopia, ZTE trained 300 engineers and IT technicians in Ethiopia before 2010, and planned to freely train 2,000 information technology-related talents for Ethiopia in 2010.
justification: Project focuses on education and skills development in IT, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Computer science and IT training course, training of IT technicians and engineers

title: China Development Bank provides RMB 10 million loan to Xinxiang Kuroda Mingliang Leather Co. Ltd. for working capital purposes (Linked to Project ID #60645)
description: On November 24, 2010, the China-Africa Development Fund (CADF) and Xinxiang Kuroda Mingliang Leather Co. Ltd. (or Xinxiang Heitianmingliang Leather Co Ltd. or 河南黑田明亮公司 or 河南黑田明亮制革有限公司) jointly held a celebration of the establishment of the China-Africa Overseas Leather Products in Sululta, a town in Oromia State. The total equity investment from CADF and Xinxiang Kuroda Mingliang Leather Co. Ltd. was RMB 170 million (see Project ID #60645). In October 2010, China-Africa Overseas Leather Products completed plant construction and equipment installation, completed fixed asset investment, and conducted trial production.   Xinxiang Kuroda Mingliang Leather Co. Ltd. then applied for an RMB 20 million loan from the Qinghai Branch of China Development Bank (CDB) due to a shortage of working capital to maintain the company's operations. On November 18, 2010, CDB's Qinghai Branch disbursed RMB 10 million as part of the China-Africa Small and Medium Enterprises Loan Program (对非中小企业专项贷款). However, in early 2017, the China Africa Overseas Leather Products Factory (Tannery) in Sululta was abandoned.   As of October 2017, 400 soldiers from Ethiopia's Ministry of Defence (MoD) reportedly moved into the factory’s premises without any formal process. China-Africa Overseas Leather Products was shut down by the Sululta City Administration for allegedly polluting the environment in early 2017. Since then, the tannery has been under the watch of its local employees after being abandoned by its Chinese managers and other operational teams.
staff_comments: CADF is a subsidiary of China Development Bank. Xinxiang Kuroda Mingliang Leather Co. Ltd. was established in 1995 as a China-Japan joint venture but in 2010-ish became a private, Chinese wholly-owned company.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Development Bank provides RMB 10 million loan to Xinxiang Kuroda Mingliang Leather Co. Ltd. for working capital purposes (Linked to Project ID #60645)

# Description
On November 24, 2010, the China-Africa Development Fund (CADF) and Xinxiang Kuroda Mingliang Leather Co. Ltd. (or Xinxiang Heitianmingliang Leather Co Ltd. or 河南黑田明亮公司 or 河南黑田明亮制革有限公司) jointly held a celebration of the establishment of the China-Africa Overseas Leather Products in Sululta, a town in Oromia State. The total equity investment from CADF and Xinxiang Kuroda Mingliang Leather Co. Ltd. was RMB 170 million (see Project ID #60645). In October 2010, China-Africa Overseas Leather Products completed plant construction and equipment installation, completed fixed asset investment, and conducted trial production.   Xinxiang Kuroda Mingliang Leather Co. Ltd. then applied for an RMB 20 million loan from the Qinghai Branch of China Development Bank (CDB) due to a shortage of working capital to maintain the company's operations. On November 18, 2010, CDB's Qinghai Branch disbursed RMB 10 million as part of the China-Africa Small and Medium Enterprises Loan Program (对非中小企业专项贷款). However, in early 2017, the China Africa Overseas Leather Products Factory (Tannery) in Sululta was abandoned.   As of October 2017, 400 soldiers from Ethiopia's Ministry of Defence (MoD) reportedly moved into the factory’s premises without any formal process. China-Africa Overseas Leather Products was shut down by the Sululta City Administration for allegedly polluting the environment in early 2017. Since then, the tannery has been under the watch of its local employees after being abandoned by its Chinese managers and other operational teams.
justification: The project involves a loan for working capital purposes to a leather manufacturing company, which does not have a clear environmental or energy transition impact.
evidence: Loan provided for working capital to maintain operations of a leather products factory, no mention of energy or environmental focus

title: China Eximbank provides $295.9 million buyer’s credit loan for 254MW Genale Dawa III Hydroelectric Power Station Project (Linked to Project ID#52938)
description: On September 1, 2010, China Eximbank and the Ethiopian Electric Power Corporation (EEPCo) signed a $295,927,736 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement for the Genale Dawa III Hydroelectric Power Station Project. The borrowing terms of the BCL were as follows: a 12 year maturity, a 3 year grace period, and a 2.43% interest rate. The Government of Ethiopia issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance a $451,058,001 commercial (EPC) contract [Contract N0.33.20/1/02)] between EEPCo and China Gezhouba Group Company (CGGC) which was signed on September 18, 2009 and modified on September 26, 2010.   According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the ETB 4,053,424,658 loan achieved a 111% disbursement rate, with China Eximbank making 15 loan disbursements (worth ETB 4,499,623,058) between 2014 and 2019: an ETB 234,280,303 disbursement on October 8, 2013, an ETB 158,812,261 disbursement on January 8, 2014, an ETB 194,174,757 disbursement on April 8, 2014, an ETB 1,200,000,000 disbursement on October 8, 2014, an ETB 404,040,404 disbursement on January 8, 2015, an ETB 265,556,593 disbursement on April 8, 2015, an ETB 102,387,246 disbursement on July 8, 2015, an ETB 405,453,493 disbursement on October 7, 2015, an ETB 153,171,320 disbursement on January 7, 2016, an ETB 244,603,535 disbursement on April 7, 2016, an ETB 145,293,164 disbursement on July 7, 2016, an ETB 27,576,322 disbursement on October 7, 2016, an ETB 522,418,088 disbursement on January 7, 2017, an ETB 45,062,662 disbursement on April 7, 2017, and an ETB 396,792,911 disbursement on March 27, 2019.   The purpose of the project was to construct the 254MW Genale-Dawa III multipurpose hydropower plant. The plant consists of a concrete faced rock fill dam and an underground powerhouse. Based on the estimated sedimentation level, the project will have a lifetime of more than 1,000 years. The dam site is located in a low seismic hazard area of class I. The dam is 110m high, 456m wide and 450m long. It is made with groutable and non-erodible rock and has a volume of 3.2 million cubic metres (mm3). At the full capacity, the dam can store up to 2,570mm3 of water. It has a catchment area of 10,445km2 and a fill volume of 890,000m3. The dam spillway is an open chute type with an ogee weir crest and three radial spillway gates. The underground powerhouse is installed with three vertical Francis turbine generators with a capacity of 84.7MW each. It is housed within an underground cavern measuring 60m-long, 20m-wide and 41m deep and also includes auxiliary equipment. A 12.4km long, 8.1m diameter headrace tunnel carries water from the dam through a 188m deep steel-lined vertical shaft to a three-pronged manifold. The manifold feeds the water to the turbine inlet valves of the three turbines housed in the powerhouse. A 820m long tailrace tunnel and a 480m long open channel returns the water back to the river. A transformer cavern is located downstream of the powerhouse and includes three step-up transformers. The electricity generated is transferred from the transformers to a 230kV/400kV switchyard located above ground through a 500m long cable tunnel.   The project area is located in Kobadi, some 400 km (air distance) south-east of Addis Ababa and some 200 km (air distance) north of the border with Kenya. The scheme, including the reservoir and power waterways, extends over a river corridor some 55 km long. The approximate centroid of the project area lies at latitude 5º 38' North and longitude 39º 43' East.   CGGC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. However, several other contractors were involved in the project. Stantec, a US-based company, provided design, planning, management and consulting services. Lahmeyer International, a German company, conducted the feasibility study. Tunnelpro, an Italy-based supplier, provided tunnel boring machines.   Project implementation commenced in March 2011 and the project was originally expected to commence on January 1, 2010 and reach completion within 48.5 months (January 15, 2014). However, the project encountered multiple implementation delays. An inauguration ceremony was held to commemorate the project’s completion on February 4, 2020. The project temporarily employed 390 Ethiopian workers.   There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the 254MW Genale Dawa III Hydroelectric Power Station Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform, as of September 2019, ICBC suspended about $67 million worth of loan disbursements 'due to [the] cross-default situation of the country’ (see Project ID#58616). Then, in August 2021, China Eximbank withheld $339 million loan disbursements for 12 projects and halted project implementation due to Government of Ethiopia’s rapidly dwindling foreign exchange reserves and debt sustainability challenges. Demisu Lemma, the Director of Chinese Cooperation at the Ethiopian Ministry of Finance, noted at the time that the Ethiopian Government was in discussions with China Eximbank about a potential debt rescheduling (that would involved a 5-year maturity extension and a 1-year grace period extension). Then, after considerable delay, the G20 Common Framework (CF) creditor committee for Ethiopia convened in September 2021, with the French Government and the Chinese Government serving as co-chairs. The CF debt rescheduling talks were still ongoing in mid-2023.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the 254MW Genale-Dawa III Hydroelectric Power Station Project, the Geneale-Dawa-Multi Purpose Hydroelectric Project, and the GD-3 Project. The Chinese project title is 埃塞GD-3水电站工程. 2. A September 26, 2010 amendment to the EPC contract between Gezhouba Group Company Limited and Ethiopian Electric Power Corporation indicates that the borrower is responsible for 15% of the EPC contract (Ethiopian Electric Power Corporation), which implies that the lender (China Eximbank) may have been responsible for 85% of the EPC contract value ($383,399,300.85). However, for the time being, AidData relies on the face value of the loan ($295,927,736) that is reported by the Ethiopia Public Sector Debt Statistical Bulletin No.7.  3. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 87143122101156. 4. 1 Ethiopian Birr (ETB) was equal to 0.060 United States Dollars (USD) in September 2010 which implies that the loan commitment value recorded in the AMP (ETB 4,053,424,658) was equivalent to USD 243,205,479.48. SAIS-CARI identifies the face value of the loan as $270 million, which is roughly equivalent to 60% of the cost of the 2010 commercial (EPC) contract between EEPCo and CGGC. 5. Ethiopia Public Sector Debt Statistical Bulletin No.7. identifies the loan commitment date as October 27, 2010. The AMP identifies the loan commitment date as September 1, 2010. This discrepancy warrants further investigation. 6.  In 2009, the Government of Ethiopia and China Eximbank signed a $400 million general buyer’s credit loan agreement for multiple road and power projects, including the 254MW Genale Dawa III Hydroelectric Power Station Project. It appears that the September 1, 2010 BCL represents a subsidiary loan agreement.  The September 18, 2009 EPC contract between EPPCo and CGGC can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/3qd6jedombnt50o/EPC%20Contract%20for%20the%20Genale-Dawa%28GD3%29%20Multipurpose%20Hydropower%20Project.pdf?dl=0. 7.  Project ID#69129 captures the China Eximbank loan for the construction of this power station. The transmission portion of the power station, funded by a different China Eximbank loan, is captured via Project ID#52938
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $295.9 million buyer’s credit loan for 254MW Genale Dawa III Hydroelectric Power Station Project (Linked to Project ID#52938)

# Description
On September 1, 2010, China Eximbank and the Ethiopian Electric Power Corporation (EEPCo) signed a $295,927,736 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement for the Genale Dawa III Hydroelectric Power Station Project. The borrowing terms of the BCL were as follows: a 12 year maturity, a 3 year grace period, and a 2.43% interest rate. The Government of Ethiopia issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan. The borrower was expected to use the proceeds of the loan to partially finance a $451,058,001 commercial (EPC) contract [Contract N0.33.20/1/02)] between EEPCo and China Gezhouba Group Company (CGGC) which was signed on September 18, 2009 and modified on September 26, 2010.   According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the ETB 4,053,424,658 loan achieved a 111% disbursement rate, with China Eximbank making 15 loan disbursements (worth ETB 4,499,623,058) between 2014 and 2019: an ETB 234,280,303 disbursement on October 8, 2013, an ETB 158,812,261 disbursement on January 8, 2014, an ETB 194,174,757 disbursement on April 8, 2014, an ETB 1,200,000,000 disbursement on October 8, 2014, an ETB 404,040,404 disbursement on January 8, 2015, an ETB 265,556,593 disbursement on April 8, 2015, an ETB 102,387,246 disbursement on July 8, 2015, an ETB 405,453,493 disbursement on October 7, 2015, an ETB 153,171,320 disbursement on January 7, 2016, an ETB 244,603,535 disbursement on April 7, 2016, an ETB 145,293,164 disbursement on July 7, 2016, an ETB 27,576,322 disbursement on October 7, 2016, an ETB 522,418,088 disbursement on January 7, 2017, an ETB 45,062,662 disbursement on April 7, 2017, and an ETB 396,792,911 disbursement on March 27, 2019.   The purpose of the project was to construct the 254MW Genale-Dawa III multipurpose hydropower plant. The plant consists of a concrete faced rock fill dam and an underground powerhouse. Based on the estimated sedimentation level, the project will have a lifetime of more than 1,000 years. The dam site is located in a low seismic hazard area of class I. The dam is 110m high, 456m wide and 450m long. It is made with groutable and non-erodible rock and has a volume of 3.2 million cubic metres (mm3). At the full capacity, the dam can store up to 2,570mm3 of water. It has a catchment area of 10,445km2 and a fill volume of 890,000m3. The dam spillway is an open chute type with an ogee weir crest and three radial spillway gates. The underground powerhouse is installed with three vertical Francis turbine generators with a capacity of 84.7MW each. It is housed within an underground cavern measuring 60m-long, 20m-wide and 41m deep and also includes auxiliary equipment. A 12.4km long, 8.1m diameter headrace tunnel carries water from the dam through a 188m deep steel-lined vertical shaft to a three-pronged manifold. The manifold feeds the water to the turbine inlet valves of the three turbines housed in the powerhouse. A 820m long tailrace tunnel and a 480m long open channel returns the water back to the river. A transformer cavern is located downstream of the powerhouse and includes three step-up transformers. The electricity generated is transferred from the transformers to a 230kV/400kV switchyard located above ground through a 500m long cable tunnel.   The project area is located in Kobadi, some 400 km (air distance) south-east of Addis Ababa and some 200 km (air distance) north of the border with Kenya. The scheme, including the reservoir and power waterways, extends over a river corridor some 55 km long. The approximate centroid of the project area lies at latitude 5º 38' North and longitude 39º 43' East.   CGGC was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. However, several other contractors were involved in the project. Stantec, a US-based company, provided design, planning, management and consulting services. Lahmeyer International, a German company, conducted the feasibility study. Tunnelpro, an Italy-based supplier, provided tunnel boring machines.   Project implementation commenced in March 2011 and the project was originally expected to commence on January 1, 2010 and reach completion within 48.5 months (January 15, 2014). However, the project encountered multiple implementation delays. An inauguration ceremony was held to commemorate the project’s completion on February 4, 2020. The project temporarily employed 390 Ethiopian workers.   There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the 254MW Genale Dawa III Hydroelectric Power Station Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform, as of September 2019, ICBC suspended about $67 million worth of loan disbursements 'due to [the] cross-default situation of the country’ (see Project ID#58616). Then, in August 2021, China Eximbank withheld $339 million loan disbursements for 12 projects and halted project implementation due to Government of Ethiopia’s rapidly dwindling foreign exchange reserves and debt sustainability challenges. Demisu Lemma, the Director of Chinese Cooperation at the Ethiopian Ministry of Finance, noted at the time that the Ethiopian Government was in discussions with China Eximbank about a potential debt rescheduling (that would involved a 5-year maturity extension and a 1-year grace period extension). Then, after considerable delay, the G20 Common Framework (CF) creditor committee for Ethiopia convened in September 2021, with the French Government and the Chinese Government serving as co-chairs. The CF debt rescheduling talks were still ongoing in mid-2023.
justification: Primary purpose is hydroelectric power generation, a renewable energy source
evidence: 254MW Genale-Dawa III multipurpose hydropower plant with concrete faced rock fill dam and underground powerhouse

title: Chinese Government provides ETB 25.4 million grant for Nationwide Wind and Solar Energy Grid Based Master Plan Project
description: On January 11, 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ethiopia signed letters of exchange with respect to the Nationwide Wind and Solar Energy Grid Based Master Plan Project. According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), China’s Ministry of Commerce agreed to provide a grant to the Government of Ethiopia worth approximately ETB 25,466,201 to support this project.   The purpose of the project was to undertake a field investigation of wind and solar energy resources in Ethiopia, prepare an Ethiopian wind and solar energy development master plan, recommend 2 wind farm sites and a photovoltaic power station site, prepare pre-feasibility study reports for the 2 wind farms and photovoltaic power station, and provide a 30-day training of 10 Ethiopian technicians in Ethiopia and China. HydroChina International Engineering Company (HCIE) was the general contractor responsible for project implementation. On February 22, 2011, it signed an RMB 10.8 million contract with China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM). HCIE was responsible for organizing and managing the wind and solar master plan. Beijing Engineering Corporation was responsible for the implementation and design of the wind and solar master plan.   The master plan was released on August 15, 2012. By August 23, 2012, all data collection activities, site surveys, and reports were complete.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Ethiopian Wind and Solar Energy Development Planning Project. The Chinese project title is 援埃塞俄比亚风电太阳能规划项目 or 埃塞风电太阳能规划报. 2. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 87143123101134. The AMP records a grant commitment value of ETB 25,466,201 on January 11, 2010. 1 Ethiopian Birr (ETB) was equal to 0.54 Chinese yuan (RMB) in January 2010, which implies that the ETB 25,466,201 grant commitment recorded in the AMP was worth RMB 13,751,748.54 at the time that it was contracted.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government provides ETB 25.4 million grant for Nationwide Wind and Solar Energy Grid Based Master Plan Project

# Description
On January 11, 2010, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ethiopia signed letters of exchange with respect to the Nationwide Wind and Solar Energy Grid Based Master Plan Project. According to the Government of Ethiopia’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), China’s Ministry of Commerce agreed to provide a grant to the Government of Ethiopia worth approximately ETB 25,466,201 to support this project.   The purpose of the project was to undertake a field investigation of wind and solar energy resources in Ethiopia, prepare an Ethiopian wind and solar energy development master plan, recommend 2 wind farm sites and a photovoltaic power station site, prepare pre-feasibility study reports for the 2 wind farms and photovoltaic power station, and provide a 30-day training of 10 Ethiopian technicians in Ethiopia and China. HydroChina International Engineering Company (HCIE) was the general contractor responsible for project implementation. On February 22, 2011, it signed an RMB 10.8 million contract with China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM). HCIE was responsible for organizing and managing the wind and solar master plan. Beijing Engineering Corporation was responsible for the implementation and design of the wind and solar master plan.   The master plan was released on August 15, 2012. By August 23, 2012, all data collection activities, site surveys, and reports were complete.
justification: Project focuses on developing a master plan for wind and solar energy development, including site selection and feasibility studies for renewable energy projects
evidence: Field investigation of wind and solar energy resources, preparation of development master plan, recommendation of wind farm and photovoltaic power station sites, pre-feasibility study reports

title: All-China Women's Federation donates 750 sewing machines to Fiji Women's Federation (Linked to #39321)
description: On April 19, 2010, the All-China Women's Federation donated 750 sewing machines to Fiji Women's Federation, valued at 187,500 Fiji dollars (96,825 U.S. dollars). The machines were handed over and distributed to different communities to become a sustainable source of income for rural women. In 2009, China has donated 200 sewing machines, and in 2011, China donated another 1000 machines to Fiji (see Project #39321).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
All-China Women's Federation donates 750 sewing machines to Fiji Women's Federation (Linked to #39321)

# Description
On April 19, 2010, the All-China Women's Federation donated 750 sewing machines to Fiji Women's Federation, valued at 187,500 Fiji dollars (96,825 U.S. dollars). The machines were handed over and distributed to different communities to become a sustainable source of income for rural women. In 2009, China has donated 200 sewing machines, and in 2011, China donated another 1000 machines to Fiji (see Project #39321).
justification: Project focuses on social development and women's empowerment through income generation, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of sewing machines to support rural women's income generation, no energy or environmental components mentioned
